title: Banks square up to pricing inquiry
text:
The big four banks were accused of "profiteering" by the Prime Minister Scott Morrison in the wake of October's Reserve Bank rate decision after they passed 15 basis points or less of the 25 basis point rate cut to a record low 0.75 per cent.

Federal Treasurer Josh Frydenberg pulled the trigger on the competition inquiry on Monday morning after two weeks of intense campaigning for a fresh inquiry.

Mr Frydenberg said the banks' failure to pass on the cut left them open to criticism they were continuing to put profits before people.

“This is not a good outcome for either their customers or the economy as a whole, and comes just months after the royal commission shone a bright light on misconduct in the banking sector,” the Treasurer said.

ABA CEO Anna Bligh "Australia’s banks stand ready to assist the ACCC." Jessica Hromas

“With this new inquiry, the government is providing the banks with an opportunity to transparently account for their decision-making and how they balance the needs of borrowers, savers, shareholders and the wider community.”

Australian Banking Association CEO Anna Bligh said banks were willing and able to assist the inquiry however the sector's first priority was to implement the many recommendations from last year's royal commission.

Advertisement

"Banks are no stranger to public scrutiny and look forward to the opportunity to cast more light on mortgage pricing and the many important factors that influence the setting of interest rates," Mr Bligh said.

The inquiry will be run by Australian Competition and Consumer boss Ross Sims who has been agitating for an instruction to explore the issue both publicly and privately for weeks.

The ACCC last ran an inquiry into mortgage pricing in 2018 which criticised the banks for opaque pricing methods and ‘synchronised’ responses to rate cuts.

Last week Mr Sims told The Australian Financial Review he was concerned about the bank’s shabby treatment of loyal customers which is estimated to prop up bank profits by $3.1 billion each year.

Mr Sims said the banks seemed comfortable dudding longstanding customers with higher rates than those it used to entice new borrowers with, and the longer a customer stayed with a bank "the more out of kilter it seems to become".

Challenger banks were quick off the mark to score points off the announcement with ME announcing a lowest ever two-year fixed interest rate for owner-occupiers paying principal and interest of 2.88 per cent and 2.99 per cent for five-year terms.

Advertisement

After several years of inquiries and parliamentary grillings, banks are expected to be match-fit and better able to articulate the case for failing to move their mortgage rates in lock step with the RBA.

Former Westpac boss Gail Kelly’s ham-fisted 2009 analogy where the bank compared mortgage and deposit pricing decisions with a banana smoothie was among the most poorly received, attracting widespread public ridicule.

Banks have gone to great lengths in recent times to explain that pricing decisions affect a range of stakeholders including borrowers, depositors, customers and shareholders.

With rates at record lows, each successive cut has an outsized impact on bank profits as they are limited to how much they pass on before they encroach on bank margins.

At the same time, Australian banks continue to enjoy higher profits than peer banks around the world with return on equity sitting at around 12 times or more than double the ratio for European banks, many of which are hamstrung by negative interest rates.
description: Banks are poised to refute allegations they are gouging loyal customers and profiteering by withholding interest rate cuts.
